message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Policy Iteration Approach to the Infinite Horizon Average Optimal Control of Probabilistic Boolean Networks
Paper Abstract: This article studies the optimal control of probabilistic Boolean control networks (PBCNs) with the infinite horizon average cost criterion. By resorting to the semitensor product (STP) of matrices, a nested optimality equation for the optimal control problem of PBCNs is proposed. The Laurent series expression technique and the Jordan decomposition method derive a novel policy iteration-type algorithm, where finite iteration steps can provide the optimal state feedback law, which is presented. Finally, the intervention problem of the probabilistic Ara operon in E. coil, as a biological application, is solved to demonstrate the effectiveness and feasibility of the proposed theoretical approach and algorithms.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Policy Iteration"

Links: [{"title":"Markov decision process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_decision_process"},{"title":"State–action–reward–state–action","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State–action–reward–state–action"},{"title":"Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Council for National Policy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Council_for_national_policy"},{"title":"Hollow state - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hollow_state"},{"title":"Life unworthy of life - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lebensunwertes_Leben"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about Policy Iteration:

## Policy Iteration Overview

Policy iteration, developed by Howard in 1960, is a step where step one is performed once, and then step two is performed once, then both are repeated until the policy converges.

## How It Works

The algorithm has two steps: (1) a value update and (2) a policy update, which are repeated in some order for all the states until no further changes take place. Both recursively update a new estimation of the optimal policy and state value using an older estimation of those values.

## Comparison to Other Methods

Policy iteration is usually slower than value iteration for a large number of possible states.

## Modified Policy Iteration

In modified policy iteration, step one is performed once, and then step two is repeated several times. Then step one is again performed once and so on.

## Historical Context

Policy iteration was invented by Howard to optimize Sears catalogue mailing, which he had been optimizing using value iteration.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's information about Policy Iteration:

## Policy Iteration Overview

Policy iteration, developed by Howard in 1960, is a step where step one is performed once, and then step two is performed once, then both are repeated until the policy converges.

## How It Works

The algorithm has two steps: (1) a value update and (2) a policy update, which are repeated in some order for all the states until no further changes take place. Both recursively update a new estimation of the optimal policy and state value using an older estimation of those values.

## Comparison to Other Methods

Policy iteration is usually slower than value iteration for a large number of possible states.

## Modified Policy Iteration

In modified policy iteration, step one is performed once, and then step two is repeated several times. Then step one is again performed once and so on.

## Historical Context

Policy iteration was invented by Howard to optimize Sears catalogue mailing, which he had been optimizing using value iteration.

Links: [{"title":"Boolean network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_network"},{"title":"Boolean - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean"},{"title":"Logic synthesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logic_synthesis"},{"title":"Stochastic geometry models of wireless networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_geometry_models_of_wireless_networks"},{"title":"Bayesian network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayesian_network"},{"title":"Gene regulatory network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gene_regulatory_network"},{"title":"File:Hou710 BooleanNetwork.svg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Hou710_BooleanNetwork.svg"},{"title":"Functional completeness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complete_set_of_Boolean_operators"},{"title":"Boolean function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_function"},{"title":"Boolean circuit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_circuit"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about Boolean networks:

## Definition

A Boolean network is a particular kind of sequential dynamical system, where time and states are discrete. More specifically, a Boolean network consists of a discrete set of Boolean variables each of which has a Boolean function assigned to it which takes inputs from a subset of those variables and determines the state of that variable, with this set of functions determining a topology on the set of variables, which become nodes in a network.

## How They Work

The dynamics of the system is usually taken as a discrete time series where the state of the entire network at time t+1 is determined by evaluating each variable's function on the state of the network at time t, which may be done synchronously or asynchronously.

## History and Applications

The first Boolean networks were proposed by Stuart A. Kauffman in 1969, as random models of genetic regulatory networks. Boolean networks have been used in biology to model regulatory networks, and they are particularly useful for modeling gene regulatory networks despite being a simplification.

## Network Behavior

The stability of Boolean networks depends on the connections of their nodes, and a Boolean network can exhibit stable, critical or chaotic behavior. This phenomenon is governed by a critical value of the average number of connections of nodes, and can be characterized by the Hamming distance as distance measure—in the unstable regime, the distance between two initially close states on average grows exponentially in time, while in the stable regime it decreases exponentially.

Links: [{"title":"Optimal control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimal_control"},{"title":"Pseudospectral optimal control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pseudospectral_optimal_control"},{"title":"Control (optimal control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_(optimal_control_theory)"},{"title":"Unscented optimal control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unscented_optimal_control"},{"title":"Stochastic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_control"},{"title":"Machine learning control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning_control"},{"title":"Coherent control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coherent_control"},{"title":"H-infinity methods in control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H-infinity_methods_in_control_theory"},{"title":"PROPT - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PROPT"},{"title":"Witsenhausen's counterexample - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Witsenhausen's_counterexample"}]

Here are the search results for "Optimal control":

## Overview

Optimal control theory is a branch of control theory that deals with finding a control for a dynamical system over a period of time such that an objective function is optimized.(no content)It has numerous applications in science, engineering and operations research.

## Practical Examples

For example, the dynamical system might be a spacecraft with controls corresponding to rocket thrusters, and the objective might be to reach the Moon with minimum fuel expenditure.(no content)Or the dynamical system could be a nation's economy, with the objective to minimize unemployment; the controls in this case could be fiscal and monetary policy.

## Key Principles

A control problem includes a cost functional that is a function of state and control variables. An optimal control is a set of differential equations describing the paths of the control variables that minimize the cost function.(no content)The optimal control can be derived using Pontryagin's maximum principle (a necessary condition also known as Pontryagin's minimum principle or simply Pontryagin's principle), or by solving the Hamilton–Jacobi–Bellman equation (a sufficient condition).

## Historical Background

The method is largely due to the work of Lev Pontryagin and Richard Bellman in the 1950s, after contributions to calculus of variations by Edward J. McShane.

## Related Approaches

The search results also revealed several related areas:
- Stochastic control deals with the existence of uncertainty either in observations or in the noise that drives the evolution of the system.
- Adaptive Dynamic Programming (ADP), also known as approximate dynamic programming or neuro-dynamic programming, is a machine learning control method that combines reinforcement learning with dynamic programming to solve optimal control problems for complex systems.

Links: [{"title":"Jordan normal form - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jordan_normal_form"},{"title":"Jordan decomposition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jordan_decomposition"},{"title":"Jordan matrix - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jordan_matrix"},{"title":"Jordan–Chevalley decomposition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jordan–Chevalley_decomposition"},{"title":"Matrix decomposition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matrix_decomposition"},{"title":"Frobenius normal form - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frobenius_normal_form"},{"title":"Diagonalizable matrix - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diagonalizable_matrix"},{"title":"Jordan algebra - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jordan_algebra"},{"title":"Symmetric cone - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetric_cone"},{"title":"Hahn decomposition theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hahn_decomposition_theorem"}]

Here are the key results about Jordan decomposition and matrices:

## Jordan Normal Form

A Jordan normal form, also known as a Jordan canonical form, is an upper triangular matrix of a particular form called a Jordan matrix representing a linear operator on a finite-dimensional vector space with respect to some basis.(no content)Such a matrix has each non-zero off-diagonal entry equal to 1, immediately above the main diagonal (on the superdiagonal), and with identical diagonal entries to the left and below them.(no content)The Jordan form of a n × n matrix A is block diagonal, and therefore gives a decomposition of the n dimensional Euclidean space into invariant subspaces of A.(no content)The outlined squares are known as "Jordan blocks", with each Jordan block containing one number λi on its main diagonal, and 1s directly above the main diagonal.

## Jordan–Chevalley Decomposition

The Jordan–Chevalley decomposition expresses a linear operator in a unique way as the sum of two other linear operators which are simpler to understand. Specifically, one part is potentially diagonalisable and the other is nilpotent.(no content)Any square matrix M can be written as a sum D + N where D is semisimple, N is nilpotent, and DN = ND.

## Historical Note

The Jordan normal form is named after Camille Jordan, who first stated the Jordan decomposition theorem in 1870.

A Jordan normal form, also known as a Jordan canonical form, is an upper triangular matrix of a particular form called a Jordan matrix representing a linear operator on a finite-dimensional vector space with respect to some basis.(no content)Such a matrix has each non-zero off-diagonal entry equal to 1, immediately above the main diagonal (on the superdiagonal), and with identical diagonal entries to the left and below them.(no content)The Jordan form of a n × n matrix A is block diagonal, and therefore gives a decomposition of the n dimensional Euclidean space into invariant subspaces of A.(no content)The outlined squares are known as "Jordan blocks", with each Jordan block containing one number λi on its main diagonal, and 1s directly above the main diagonal.

## Jordan–Chevalley Decomposition

The Jordan–Chevalley decomposition expresses a linear operator in a unique way as the sum of two other linear operators which are simpler to understand. Specifically, one part is potentially diagonalisable and the other is nilpotent.(no content)Any square matrix M can be written as a sum D + N where D is semisimple, N is nilpotent, and DN = ND.

## Historical Note

The Jordan normal form is named after Camille Jordan, who first stated the Jordan decomposition theorem in 1870.

Web search results for query: "State feedback control"

Links: [{"title":"Full state feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Full_state_feedback"},{"title":"Feedback linearization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback_linearization"},{"title":"State observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_observer"},{"title":"Controllability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Controllability"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Ackermann's formula - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ackermann's_formula"},{"title":"Linear–quadratic regulator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear–quadratic_regulator"},{"title":"Robust control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robust_control"},{"title":"Feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback"},{"title":"State-space representation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State-space_representation"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about state feedback control:

## Overview

Full state feedback (FSF), or pole placement, is a method employed in feedback control system theory to place the closed-loop poles of a plant in predetermined locations in the s-plane.(no content)Placing poles is desirable because the location of the poles corresponds directly to the eigenvalues of the system, which control the characteristics of the response of the system.

## Key Requirements

The system must be considered controllable in order to implement this method.(no content)Complete state controllability describes the ability of an external input (the vector of control variables) to move the internal state of a system from any initial state to any final state in a finite time interval.

## How It Works

If the closed-loop dynamics can be represented by the state space equation, then the poles of the system transfer function are the roots of the characteristic equation. Consider an input proportional (in the matrix sense) to the state vector.(no content)Comparing the terms of this equation with those of the desired characteristic equation yields the values of the feedback matrix which force the closed-loop eigenvalues to the pole locations specified by the desired characteristic equation.

## Practical Applications

For MIMO systems, pole placement can be performed mathematically using a state space representation of the open-loop system and calculating a feedback matrix assigning poles in the desired positions.(no content)The LQR algorithm is essentially an automated way of finding an appropriate state-feedback controller. As such, it is not uncommon for control engineers to prefer alternative methods, like full state feedback, also known as pole placement, in which there is a clearer relationship between controller parameters and controller behavior.

Based on the search results, here's information about Laurent series:

## Definition and Overview

A Laurent series is a representation of a function as a power series which includes terms of negative degree, and may be used to express complex functions in cases where a Taylor series expansion cannot be applied.

## Historical Background

The Laurent series was named after and first published by Pierre Alphonse Laurent in 1843, though Karl Weierstrass had previously described it in a paper written in 1841 but not published until 1894.

## Key Applications and Properties

Laurent series with complex coefficients are an important tool in complex analysis, especially to investigate the behavior of functions near singularities, and can be used to express holomorphic functions defined on an annulus, much as power series are used to express holomorphic functions defined on a disc.

## Principal Part

The principal part of a Laurent series is the series of terms with negative degree.

## Laurent Polynomials

A Laurent polynomial is a Laurent series in which only finitely many coefficients are non-zero, and they differ from ordinary polynomials in that they may have terms of negative degree.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title, relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

Perfect! I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Classification:** **Contribution** - The paper proposes a novel policy iteration-type algorithm for optimal control of probabilistic Boolean networks.

**Key Entities Extracted:**

1. **Policy Iteration** (method, uses) - Extended to probabilistic Boolean networks with average cost criteria
2. **Boolean Network** (concept, uses) - The foundational discrete dynamical system framework
3. **Optimal Control** (task, uses) - The underlying mathematical framework for finding optimal control laws
4. **Full State Feedback** (method, proposes) - A novel optimal state feedback law derived by the paper
5. **Jordan Normal Form** (concept, uses) - Mathematical technique for solving optimality equations
6. **Laurent Series** (concept, uses) - Mathematical technique for expressing and solving equations

**Validation Status:** ✅ All checks passed successfully!

The triples_output.json file has been properly formatted with:
- Correct Wikipedia URLs for all entities
- Appropriate entity types and relations
- Clear relevance descriptions for each triple
- All validation requirements met (6 triples, at least 1 "uses" and 1 "proposes")
